data.title: SEACOR Marine Holdings (SMHI) EPS Loss Reinforces Bearish Earnings Decline Narrative
data.description:
SEACOR Marine Holdings (SMHI) closed FY 2025 with Q4 revenue of US$52.3 million and a basic EPS loss of US$0.57, while the trailing 12 month figures show revenue of US$227.8 million and a basic EPS loss of US$1.06. Over the past six quarters, the company has seen quarterly revenue move between US$52.3 million and US$69.8 million, with EPS ranging from a loss of US$0.94 to a profit of US$0.35. This puts the latest results in the context of uneven profitability and tight margins. For investors, a key consideration after this report is how quickly those margins might firm up enough to support a more durable earnings profile.

See our full analysis for SEACOR Marine Holdings.

With the headline numbers on the table, the next step is to see how this earnings profile lines up with the prevailing narratives around growth, profitability, and risk that many investors have been following.

Curious how numbers become stories that shape markets? Explore Community Narratives

Advertisement

Trailing 12 Months Still Show US$27.8 Million Loss

  • On a trailing 12 month basis, SMHI generated US$227.8 million of revenue but reported a net loss of US$27.8 million and a basic EPS loss of US$1.06, so the full year picture is still firmly in loss making territory even with periods of positive EPS in individual quarters.
  • Bears highlight that forecasts point to earnings declining by about 24.5% per year over the next three years, and the current loss profile aligns with that concern, as:
    • The latest four quarters together show losses in three of them, with quarterly net losses as large as US$15.5 million in FY 2025 Q1.
    • Over the last year, the company remained unprofitable despite revenue of more than US$200 million, which fits the bearish view that profitability is not yet in sight.

Revenue Trend Around US$228 Million With Modest 2.9% Growth

  • Revenue over the trailing 12 months sits at US$227.8 million, and the data indicates revenue growth of about 2.9% per year, which is slower than the referenced US market growth expectation of 10.4% per year.
  • Critics argue that modest revenue growth combined with expected earnings decline limits the near term appeal, and the current figures give that view some support, since:
    • Quarterly revenue over the last six quarters stayed in a fairly tight band between US$52.3 million and US$69.8 million, without a clear jump that might quickly change margins.
    • The forecast that revenue grows at 2.9% per year while earnings are expected to decline signals that higher sales alone may not be enough to change the loss making pattern.

P/S Of 0.9x Versus Industry And Peers

  • SMHI trades on a P/S of 0.9x, which is lower than the US Energy Services industry average of 1.3x but higher than its peer group average of 0.7x, so the shares sit between broader sector pricing and closer peers.
  • What stands out for cautious investors is how this mixed valuation lines up with the risk profile, because:
    • Forecasts indicate SMHI is expected to remain unprofitable and earnings are expected to decline by about 24.5% per year, yet the stock still trades at a small premium to peers on P/S.
    • The company has less than one year of cash runway, which keeps attention on liquidity while investors weigh whether a below industry but above peer P/S multiple is comfortable for a loss making business.

data.title: Summit Hotel Properties (INN) EPS Loss Deepens In Q4 2025 Challenging Bullish Margin Narratives
data.description:
Advertisement

Summit Hotel Properties FY 2025 earnings: revenue steady as EPS remains in the red

Summit Hotel Properties (INN) has wrapped up FY 2025 with fourth quarter revenue of US$175 million and basic EPS of a US$0.05 loss, keeping the focus firmly on how its income statement is holding up against ongoing pressures. The company has seen quarterly revenue move from US$172.9 million in Q4 2024 to US$175 million in Q4 2025, while basic EPS shifted from US$0.01 to a loss of US$0.05 over the same period, which keeps margins front and center for investors assessing how much earnings power is being squeezed.

See our full analysis for Summit Hotel Properties.

With the latest numbers on the table, the next step is to see how this earnings profile lines up with the prevailing narratives around growth, profitability, and risk that investors have been debating over the past year.

See what the community is saying about Summit Hotel Properties

Trailing 12 months still in loss territory

  • On a trailing 12 month basis to Q4 2025, Summit booked US$729.5 million in revenue and a net loss of US$23.6 million, with basic EPS of a US$0.22 loss.
  • Consensus narrative talks about low new hotel supply and recovering travel as supports for stronger RevPAR and margins. However, the trailing loss and negative margins show that, so far, the company is not capturing enough profitability from that backdrop.
    • Revenue over the last 12 months is broadly similar to the US$731.8 million level cited a year earlier, which contrasts with the view that limited new supply should be driving stronger top line momentum.
    • Analysts also expect revenue to grow around 2% a year while the business stays unprofitable, which keeps the consensus claim of improving margins under pressure until the income statement actually moves back into the black.

Quarterly EPS losses and the bullish story

  • Across FY 2025, every quarter showed a basic EPS loss, ranging from a US$0.01 loss in Q2 2025 to a US$0.11 loss in Q3 2025, compared with a small profit of US$0.01 per share in Q4 2024.
  • Bulls point to potential margin expansion and reduced losses over multiple years, but the run of quarterly EPS losses in 2025 sits awkwardly against that. This suggests the bullish view is leaning heavily on future improvements rather than what is currently visible in the reported numbers.
    • For example, Q3 2025 showed revenue of US$177.1 million with a net loss of US$11.5 million, which does not yet reflect the higher margin story bulls are expecting from cost control and capital recycling.
    • Even in Q2 2025, where the loss narrowed to US$1.6 million on US$192.9 million of revenue, the company still did not produce positive EPS, so investors following the bullish view may want to watch whether that quarter proves repeatable or not.

Bulls argue that limited new hotel supply and higher travel demand could be the turning point for Summit, but the current streak of quarterly EPS losses shows exactly why they see more upside if margins start to move their way. üêÇ Summit Hotel Properties Bull Case

Valuation gap vs DCF and bearish concerns

  • The shares trade at US$4.65 compared with a DCF fair value of about US$6.04, and the P/S ratio of 0.7x sits well below the 4.2x average for Global Hotel and Resort REITs.
  • Bears focus on high leverage, weak interest coverage, and forecasts of earnings declining an average 34.6% a year over the next three years. That combination helps explain why the market price stays below the DCF fair value and well under the US$5.63 analyst target, despite the apparently low P/S multiple.
    • Interest payments are described as not well covered by earnings, which fits with the trailing 12 month net loss of US$23.6 million and keeps financing risk front of mind for cautious investors.
    • With revenue only expected to grow around 2% a year, slower than the 10.4% US market forecast, skeptics can argue that a discount to both the 6.04 DCF fair value and the 5.63 target price is not surprising while profitability and coverage ratios look stretched.

Skeptics warn that weak interest coverage and ongoing losses could matter more than the apparent valuation discount, which is why many are watching how quickly earnings and cash coverage improve relative to debt costs. üêª Summit Hotel Properties Bear Case

data.title: Climb Global Solutions (CLMB) Margin Compression Tests Bullish Earnings Growth Narrative
data.description:
Climb Global Solutions (CLMB) closed FY 2025 with fourth quarter revenue of US$193.8 million and basic EPS of US$1.54, as investors weighed these results against its recent 17.5% earnings growth over the past year. The company has seen quarterly revenue move from US$161.8 million and EPS of US$1.52 in Q4 2024 to US$193.8 million and EPS of US$1.54 in Q4 2025. Trailing twelve month EPS reached US$4.71 on revenue of US$652.5 million, setting the stage for investors to balance earnings momentum against some pressure on margins.

See our full analysis for Climb Global Solutions.

With the latest figures on the table, the next step is to see how these results line up with the widely held stories about Climb Global Solutions and where the numbers start to challenge those narratives.

See what the community is saying about Climb Global Solutions

Advertisement

Margins Under Pressure At 3.3%

  • Trailing net profit margin sits at 3.3%, compared with 3.9% a year earlier, on trailing twelve month revenue of US$652.5 million and net income of US$21.3 million.
  • Critics highlight that low and contracting margins could cap earnings power, and the margin move from 3.9% to 3.3% lines up with that concern,
    • the consensus narrative talks about gross margins around the 5% range and the need to grow higher margin solutions and services, which ties directly to this margin squeeze at the net level
    • at the same time, earnings still grew 17.5% over the past year, so the bearish focus on margin pressure has to be weighed against the fact that profits have continued to rise in absolute terms
Bears warn that thin margins and integration risk could limit upside even with earnings growth showing up in the latest numbers. üêª Climb Global Solutions Bear Case

17.5% Earnings Growth Versus Modest Revenue Trend

  • Over the last year, earnings grew 17.5% while revenue growth is described as modest at about 1.2% per year in the provided context, with trailing twelve month EPS at US$4.71 on revenue of US$652.5 million.
  • Consensus narrative suggests that adding high growth vendors, expanding internationally and investing in automation can support strong and sustained earnings growth,
    • the 17.5% trailing earnings growth and roughly 25% per year compound earnings growth over five years are consistent with that bullish view on profit expansion
    • however, the modest 1.2% revenue growth versus a 10.4% US market pace shows that top line momentum is slower than the broader market, which is an important counterpoint for that optimistic storyline

Mixed Signals From P/E And DCF Fair Value

  • CLMB trades on a 19.1x P/E with a share price of US$90.03, below the US Electronic industry average of 28.3x but above its peer average of 13.5x, and well under a DCF fair value of about US$208.35 and an analyst price target of US$133.00.
  • What stands out in the bullish argument is the gap between current price and value estimates,
    • supporters can point to the roughly 56.8% difference between the US$90.03 share price and the DCF fair value of about US$208.35 as evidence that the market is not fully reflecting trailing earnings growth of 17.5%
    • yet the fact that CLMB trades richer than peers on P/E at 19.1x versus 13.5x means skeptics can argue that some of that growth is already acknowledged, even if the stock is cheaper than the broader industry and below the US$133.00 analyst target
Bulls argue that the wide gap to DCF fair value and earnings track record could matter more than the premium to peers. üêÇ Climb Global Solutions Bull Case

data.title: Hormel Foods (HRL) Margin Compression Tests Bullish Earnings Growth Narrative In Q1 2026
data.description:
Hormel Foods (HRL) opened fiscal Q1 2026 with revenue of about US$3.0 billion and basic EPS of US$0.33, setting a clear snapshot of where the business stands as earnings season gets underway. The company has seen quarterly revenue move in a tight band around US$3.0 billion over the past year, while basic EPS has ranged from a loss of roughly US$0.10 in Q4 2025 to US$0.40 in Q4 2024. This gives investors a mixed but data rich backdrop for judging this quarter. With trailing net profit margin at 4% versus 6.4% a year earlier and earnings forecast to grow faster than revenue, the key question now is how durable Hormel‚Äôs margin profile really looks.

See our full analysis for Hormel Foods.

With the latest numbers on the table, the next step is to line them up against the widely held narratives around Hormel‚Äôs growth, income appeal, and margin pressure to see which stories hold up and which need a rethink.

See what the community is saying about Hormel Foods

Advertisement

Net Income Swings and Margin Pressure

  • Over the last six quarters, net income has moved from a loss of US$56.1 million in Q4 2025 to US$181.8 million in Q1 2026, while trailing 12 month profit stands at US$489.4 million on US$12.1b of revenue, aligning with the 4% net margin figure.
  • Bears focus on profitability pressure, and the numbers give them some support alongside some pushback.
    • Trailing net margin at 4% versus 6.4% a year earlier lines up with concerns about margin compression from volatile input costs like pork, beef, and nuts.
    • At the same time, recent quarterly net income in the US$170 million to US$184 million range across most of the last five quarters, apart from Q4 2025, suggests earnings have remained relatively steady even as longer term margins have tightened.
Over the last year Hormel‚Äôs margin strain has been a key talking point for skeptics, so this mix of steady recent profits and lower trailing margins makes the bear case more nuanced than a simple profitability decline story. üêª Hormel Foods Bear Case

EPS Stability vs Forecast Growth Story

  • Basic EPS has hovered around US$0.31 to US$0.33 in four of the last five quarters, with a Q4 2025 loss and a Q4 2024 EPS of US$0.40 as the outliers, while earnings are forecast to grow about 11.18% per year compared with roughly 2% revenue growth.
  • The consensus narrative that earnings growth can run ahead of sales growth is tested by this steady but unspectacular EPS pattern.
    • Trailing 12 month EPS of US$0.89 compares with quarterly EPS near US$0.33 in Q1 2026 and Q3 2025, which is below the US$0.40 level seen in Q4 2024 and below earlier trailing EPS figures like US$1.47 a year ago.
    • Forecasts calling for earnings to grow faster than revenue suggest better margins over time, yet today‚Äôs trailing 4% net margin and flat recent EPS band show that the margin uplift implied by those forecasts is not visible in the recent history supplied.

Rich P/E, Dividend Strain and DCF Upside

  • Hormel trades on a trailing P/E of 27.9x versus 24.2x for the broader US Food industry and 13.2x for peers, while offering a 4.71% dividend yield that is not well covered by earnings or free cash flow, and a DCF fair value of US$48.41 compared with a current share price of US$24.82.
  • Bulls point to long term earnings growth and valuation upside, and the figures both support and complicate that view.
    • The stock price of US$24.82 sitting well below the DCF fair value of US$48.41 fits the optimistic claim of meaningful upside if earnings forecasts are met.
    • However, the combination of a premium 27.9x P/E, a 4% trailing net margin, and a dividend that is not well covered means the bullish argument depends heavily on the expected margin improvement and cash generation that are not yet reflected in the trailing data.
If you are weighing that richer P/E and stretched dividend against the potential DCF upside, it is worth seeing how bullish investors connect these earnings trends to their long term case for Hormel. üêÇ Hormel Foods Bull Case

data.title: Is Astec Industries (ASTE) Attractive After Strong 1 Year Rally And DCF Upside?
data.description:
• If you are wondering whether Astec Industries' current share price lines up with its underlying worth, this is a good place to break that question down calmly and clearly.
  • The stock closed at US$62.34, with returns of 8.5% over 7 days, 28.8% over 30 days, 39.7% year to date, 76.1% over 1 year and 32.7% over 3 years, while the 5 year return sits at a 4.9% decline.
  • Recent news around Astec Industries has focused on its position in capital goods and how the company is being evaluated against peers in the sector. That context helps frame whether these returns are being driven more by changing expectations for the business or by broader sentiment toward the industry.
  • On our simple 6 point value checklist, Astec Industries scores 3 out of 6. We will unpack this score using earnings based, cash flow based and asset based valuation methods, before finishing with a different way to think about fair value that many investors overlook.

Astec Industries delivered 76.1% returns over the last year. See how this stacks up to the rest of the Machinery industry.

Advertisement

Approach 1: Astec Industries Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) Analysis

A Discounted Cash Flow, or DCF, model estimates what a company might be worth by projecting its future cash flows and discounting them back to today in dollar terms. It is essentially asking what those future dollars are worth right now.

For Astec Industries, the model used is a 2 Stage Free Cash Flow to Equity approach. The company‚Äôs last twelve months of Free Cash Flow is reported at about $28.24 million. Analysts provide explicit forecasts out to 2027, with Free Cash Flow projected at $82.10 million in that year, and Simply Wall St extends those forecasts further using its own assumptions, out to 2035, keeping everything in dollars and in millions.

When all those projected cash flows are discounted back to today under this model, the estimated intrinsic value comes out at about $86.31 per share. Compared with the recent share price of $62.34, the DCF suggests Astec Industries trades at roughly a 27.8% discount, which screens as undervalued on this measure.

Result: UNDERVALUED

Our Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) analysis suggests Astec Industries is undervalued by 27.8%. Track this in your watchlist or portfolio, or discover 53 more high quality undervalued stocks.

Head to the Valuation section of our Company Report for more details on how we arrive at this Fair Value for Astec Industries.

Approach 2: Astec Industries Price vs Earnings

For profitable companies like Astec Industries, the P/E ratio is a useful way to link what you pay for the stock to the earnings the business is currently generating. It is a quick way to see how many dollars investors are paying for each dollar of earnings.

What counts as a ‚Äúnormal‚Äù P/E depends on how the market views a company‚Äôs growth prospects and risks. Higher expected growth or lower perceived risk can justify a higher multiple, while slower growth or higher uncertainty can point to a lower one.

Astec Industries currently trades on a P/E of 36.75x. That sits above the Machinery industry average of about 28.70x and below the peer group average of roughly 41.03x. Simply Wall St‚Äôs Fair Ratio for Astec Industries is 30.79x, which is its view of what a reasonable P/E would be after factoring in elements such as earnings growth, profit margins, industry, market cap and company specific risks.

This Fair Ratio can be more informative than a simple comparison with peers or the industry, because it adjusts for those business specific characteristics rather than assuming all companies deserve the same multiple. With the actual P/E of 36.75x sitting above the Fair Ratio of 30.79x, Astec Industries appears overvalued on this metric.

Result: OVERVALUED

P/E ratios tell one story, but what if the real opportunity lies elsewhere? Start investing in legacies, not executives. Discover our 19 top founder-led companies.

Upgrade Your Decision Making: Choose your Astec Industries Narrative

Earlier we mentioned that there is an even better way to think about valuation, and on Simply Wall St this is done through Narratives. You set out your story for Astec Industries, link that story to a forecast for revenue, earnings and margins, and end up with your own Fair Value that you can compare with today‚Äôs price on the Community page. This page is used by millions of investors, so your view updates automatically when new news or earnings arrive. You can see, for example, one investor building a Narrative that supports a Fair Value of about US$86 per share, while another, more cautious view aligns with a Fair Value closer to US$56.50. Each uses the same company but very different expectations to decide whether the current price looks attractive or not.

data.description:
Titan International (TWI) has wrapped up FY 2025 with fourth quarter revenue of US$410.4 million and a basic EPS loss of US$0.88, alongside a full year trailing revenue base of about US$1.8 billion and a net loss of US$63.5 million. The company has seen quarterly revenue range from US$383.6 million in Q4 2024 to US$490.7 million in Q1 2025, while basic EPS has swung from a small profit of US$0.02 in Q4 2024 to progressively larger quarterly losses through 2025. This sets the stage for a results season in which investors will focus squarely on how margins are holding up against this revenue line.

TTM loss of US$63.5 million despite US$1.8b revenue base

  • Bulls point out that analyst models in the data set call for earnings growth of about 151.5% per year and a move to profitability within three years. That view sits against a five year history where losses widened at roughly 13.2% per year and the latest TTM period still shows US$63.5 million in losses, so the optimistic case leans heavily on a future margin shift that is not visible in these reported numbers.

Quarterly losses widened sharply in Q4 2025

  • Q4 2025 net income excluding extra items was a loss of US$56.0 million on revenue of US$410.4 million, compared with smaller quarterly losses earlier in 2025 that ranged from about US$0.6 million to US$4.5 million on revenues between US$460.8 million and US$490.7 million.
  • Bears argue that dependence on cyclical equipment demand and large OEM customers could keep earnings under pressure. The pattern in 2025, where quarterly losses moved from roughly US$0.6 million in Q1 to US$56.0 million by Q4 while revenue stayed within a US$410 million to US$491 million band, gives their argument support that profitability has been fragile even without a collapse in the top line.
    • The data also shows that over the last five years, losses widened at about 13.2% per year, which fits with the cautious view that earnings volatility and operating leverage have worked against shareholders recently.
    • With the share price at US$9.90 and the business still loss making over the last twelve months, skeptics may question how quickly any forecast profit recovery can show through in reported EPS.

Bears warn that the latest step up in quarterly losses could signal that tighter OEM spending or cost pressure bites harder than optimistic scenarios assume, especially if order patterns stay uneven.

Mixed valuation signals at US$9.90 share price

  • The data shows a P/S of 0.3x compared with a peer average of 1.7x and a US Machinery industry average of 2.3x. A DCF fair value of US$7.71 per share sits below the current US$9.90 price.

That leaves less room for error if revenue growth of 3.7% per year and recent loss trends persist instead of quickly swinging toward the earnings levels implied by an 11.25 analyst target.
    • Consensus expectations in the data look for revenue growth of 5.5% per year and margins moving from about 1.2% loss making today to a 2.5% profit margin by 2028, so the gap between those future assumptions and today‚Äôs US$63.5 million loss is what investors are effectively paying for at US$9.90.

data.title: Koppers Holdings (KOP) Earnings Rebound And 3% Margin Test Bullish Improvement Narrative
data.description:
Koppers Holdings (KOP) has wrapped up FY 2025 with fourth quarter revenue of US$432.7 million and basic EPS of US$1.52, while trailing twelve month figures show revenue of about US$1.9 billion and EPS of US$2.82. Over recent periods, quarterly revenue has ranged from US$456.5 million to US$504.8 million in FY 2025, with basic EPS moving from a loss of US$0.68 in Q1 2025 to US$1.21 in Q3 2025 and US$1.12 in Q3 2024. This sets up a story where modest earnings growth, a 3% net margin and a low trailing P/E sit alongside a history of weaker multi year earnings and a sizeable one off loss that still shapes the margin picture.

See our full analysis for Koppers Holdings.

With the latest numbers on the table, the next step is to see how this mix of margins, earnings and valuation lines up with the prevailing narratives around Koppers and where those stories might need a rethink.

See what the community is saying about Koppers Holdings

Advertisement

3% net margin still relatively thin

  • Over the last 12 months, Koppers converted US$1.9b of revenue into US$56 million of net income, which works out to a 3% net margin compared with 2.5% a year earlier.
  • Consensus narrative talks about long term margin strength from efficiency projects and portfolio clean up, yet the current 3% margin and the US$78.6 million one off loss show that profitability is still sensitive to shocks and not yet at the mid to high teens margin range that bullish investors are hoping for.
    • Quarterly net income excluding extras moved from a loss of US$13.9 million in Q1 2025 to a profit of US$29.7 million in Q4 2025, which supports the idea of improving operations but also highlights how wide the swing can be.
    • With trailing earnings having declined on average by 17.9% per year over five years, the recent 6.9% earnings growth versus that trend is helpful for the bullish case but not yet a clean break from the longer track record.

Bulls argue that recent margin gains are the first step toward the higher profitability story many are watching for, and they will want to see whether the current 3% net margin can move closer to the levels discussed in their thesis. üêÇ Koppers Holdings Bull Case

Debt coverage still a key weak spot

  • Analysts highlight that debt is not well covered by operating cash flow on the trailing 12 months, even though net profit margin ticked up to 3% and earnings rose 6.9% versus the multi year trend.
  • Skeptics focus on this weak debt coverage and the 17.9% annual earnings decline over five years as signs that higher margins alone may not be enough, especially if housing, rail and industrial demand stays soft for longer than the cautious narrative assumes.
    • The one off loss of US$78.6 million in the last 12 months is a concrete example bears can point to when they argue that unexpected hits can quickly pressure cash flow and limit room to pay down debt.
    • Management targets net leverage of 2x to 3x over time, and the bearish commentary notes that current leverage is above that range, which keeps financing and interest cost risk front and center for more conservative investors.

Bears warn that until operating cash flow covers debt more comfortably, any slip in margins or volumes could matter more than the recent 6.9% uptick in trailing earnings. üêª Koppers Holdings Bear Case

Low 13x P/E versus peers

  • Koppers currently trades on a trailing P/E of 13x, which sits below the peer average of 21x, the US Chemicals industry at 24.4x, and the broader US market at 19.4x.
  • Consensus narrative suggests long term earnings growth from infrastructure demand, sustainability themes and portfolio reshaping, and the gap between the US$37.24 share price and the US$52.50 analyst target highlights how much of that improvement investors think is not yet reflected in the current 13x multiple.
    • Analysts expect earnings to reach US$245 million by around September 2028 with EPS of US$11.99, which is a large step up from the US$15.1 million earnings in the latest trailing set, so the current multiple is being weighed against a much higher future profit base in their model.
    • For that target to make sense on their numbers, Koppers would trade at a P/E of 5.3x those 2028 earnings, which is far below the current 24.4x industry level and shows how much of the upside case depends on both earnings growth and the market still applying a modest multiple.

data.title: Ingevity (NGVT) Q4 Loss Deepens And Tests Bullish Margin Turnaround Narratives
data.description:
Advertisement

Ingevity (NGVT) posts mixed FY 2025 finish as earnings swing

Ingevity (NGVT) just closed FY 2025 with Q4 revenue of US$255.1 million and basic EPS of a US$2.21 loss, a sharp contrast to Q4 FY 2024 when revenue was US$298.8 million and EPS was US$0.46. Over recent quarters the company has seen revenue move from US$340.1 million in Q1 2024 to US$284 million in Q1 2025, and from US$333.8 million in Q3 2024 to US$333.1 million in Q3 2025. Quarterly EPS has ranged from a US$1.54 loss in Q1 2024 to US$1.31 in Q3 2024 and US$1.12 in Q3 2025, before slipping back into the red in the latest quarter. This sets up a results season in which investors are likely to focus squarely on how quickly margins can stabilize from here.

See our full analysis for Ingevity.

With the headline numbers on the table, the next step is to see how this earnings print lines up against the main stories circulating around Ingevity, highlighting where the fresh data backs those narratives and where it pushes back.

See what the community is saying about Ingevity

Trailing losses still weigh on the story

  • On a trailing 12 month basis, Ingevity generated US$1.17b of revenue but reported a net loss of US$150.3 million and basic EPS of US$4.15 loss, so the company is still unprofitable over the full year even though some individual quarters were positive.
  • Analysts' consensus view points to a business in transition, with portfolio changes and cost work expected to support more resilient margins over time, yet the current loss profile shows the company is not there yet.
    • Consensus commentary highlights efforts like divesting lower margin operations and focusing on higher value specialty chemicals as potential support for future margin stability, but the latest trailing numbers still reflect weak earnings quality.
    • The same consensus view references investments in areas such as EV related materials and process purification as future growth drivers, which sit against a starting point of modest revenue growth of about 3.5% per year and sustained losses over the past five years.

Revenue growth modest versus expectations

  • Revenue over the last year implies about 3.5% annual growth, compared with a 10.4% growth rate forecast for the wider US market, so Ingevity is growing but at a slower pace than that broader benchmark.
  • Looking at the bullish angle, forecasts for earnings to turn positive and grow very quickly rest on this modest top line, which creates a clear tension.
    • Supporters of the bullish view point to analysts expecting profit margins to move from a current level of roughly 16.3% loss to a positive 28.4% in about three years, even though recent quarterly net income excluding extra items ranged from a loss of US$78.8 million in Q4 2025 to a profit of US$47.5 million in Q3 2024.
    • Those same forecasts see earnings reaching US$412.8 million and EPS of US$5.9 by around 2028, which would be a very large swing from the current trailing loss of US$150.3 million and basic EPS of US$4.15 loss, so anyone relying on the bullish case needs to be comfortable with that jump.
On these numbers, bulls are effectively betting that a modest 3.5% revenue growth path can still support a very large earnings swing, which is a big assumption to weigh. üêÇ Ingevity Bull Case

Valuation and debt pull in opposite directions

  • The shares trade on a P/S of 2.2x compared with 1.2x for the US Chemicals industry and 1.3x for peers, while a DCF fair value of about US$119.88 per share sits well above the current share price of US$70.52, so simple multiples and the DCF signal send different messages.
  • Bears focus on the combination of high leverage and these richer P/S multiples, arguing that this mix could be a risk if the forecast turnaround does not play out as modeled.
    • The company has been flagged as having a high level of debt at the same time as trailing earnings remain negative, which leaves less room for error if revenue growth stays around 3.5% a year rather than moving higher.
    • Critics also point to the five year record of losses worsening at about 61.7% per year as a challenge for a cautious view, because it shows that the business has not yet translated its revenue base of roughly US$1.17b a year into consistent positive net income.
With richer P/S multiples, a high debt load, and a DCF fair value of US$119.88 against a share price of US$70.52, skeptics will likely keep asking how quickly the company can improve profitability to justify both the balance sheet risk and the valuation signals. üêª Ingevity Bear Case

Over recent periods the company has seen quarterly revenue move from ‚Ç¨348.8 million in Q4 2024 to ‚Ç¨486.2 million in Q4 2025, with net income excluding extra items shifting from ‚Ç¨63.9 million to ‚Ç¨197.5 million over the same stretch.   • Over the last 12 months, Vopak converted ‚Ç¨1,459.3 million of revenue into ‚Ç¨604.0 million of net income, giving a 41.4% net margin compared with 28.3% a year earlier, helped by a ‚Ç¨146.9 million non recurring gain.
  • Bulls argue that this kind of margin profile supports the idea that energy transition and higher occupancy projects can keep earnings resilient. However, the reliance on a one off gain means investors need to separate underlying profitability from the ‚Ç¨146.9 million boost when deciding how much weight to put on the bullish case.
    • On the bullish side, the trailing 12 month earnings growth of 60.8% and a 5 year earnings growth rate of 26.2% a year line up with the view that portfolio optimisation and higher value terminals are already feeding through to the bottom line.
    • At the same time, the presence of that large non recurring item is listed as a risk, which challenges the idea that current margin levels can be taken as a clean read through for future earnings power.

  • Consensus narrative points out that this discount sits alongside a reported dividend yield of 3.44%, creating a mix of income and lower P/E that some investors may see as attractive, while others focus on the tension between the current price and the lower DCF fair value.

  • Bears argue that high debt and exposure to fossil fuel and chemical storage, together with these forecast declines, could pressure cash flows, which aligns with the data showing expected drops in revenue and earnings despite the solid trailing 12 month numbers.
    • The combination of a 41.4% net margin today and forecasts for earnings to fall around 16.1% a year highlights the concern that current profitability sits above what analysts see as sustainable as the business mix shifts and legacy assets mature.
    • High leverage is listed as a risk alongside those forecast declines, so cautious investors will be watching how earnings trends evolve relative to that debt load rather than focusing only on the recent margin strength.

data.title: Terreno Realty Refines Coastal Logistics Footprint With New Leases And Acquisitions
data.description:
• Terreno Realty (NYSE:TRNO) reported new full building leases in Redondo Beach, CA with a domestic energy company in the past week.
  • The company also secured a lease with a manufacturer in Rancho Dominguez, expanding its tenant mix in Southern California.
  • In New York, Terreno Realty acquired industrial properties in the Bronx and Queens with plans for redevelopment.
  • These moves affect the company‚Äôs leasing profile, tenant base, and geographic footprint in core U.S. logistics markets.

Terreno Realty focuses on industrial real estate in coastal U.S. markets that serve freight, distribution, and last mile logistics. For investors following NYSE:TRNO, the recent leasing activity in California and property acquisitions in New York are consistent with that core business model. Industrial properties tied to distribution and warehouse needs remain central to many supply chain discussions.

These new leases and planned redevelopments provide more current data points on where Terreno Realty is active and what types of tenants are occupying its buildings. As additional information becomes available on lease terms, redevelopment timing, and occupancy, investors can evaluate how these transactions align with their own view of the company‚Äôs long term positioning in major coastal hubs.

Stay updated on the most important news stories for Terreno Realty by adding it to your watchlist or portfolio. Alternatively, explore our Community to discover new perspectives on Terreno Realty.

4 things going right for Terreno Realty that this headline doesn't cover.

The recent moves in California and New York point to Terreno Realty trying to tighten up how its portfolio is used rather than simply adding square footage. On the West Coast, locking in three full building leases in Redondo Beach with a single domestic energy tenant, plus a long dated lease in Rancho Dominguez with a laboratory products company, gives better visibility on occupancy in key infill logistics submarkets. Terminating an in place lease slightly early to accommodate the new Redondo Beach agreements suggests Terreno is prioritizing tenant profile and lease length over a short period of remaining income from the prior tenant.

Advertisement

The Risks and Rewards Investors Should Consider

  • ‚ö†Ô∏è Execution risk around the Bronx and Queens projects, where planned demolition, interior build out and reconfiguration need to be finished on time and within the US$12.2m and US$103.4m expected investment levels.
  • ‚ö†Ô∏è The US$500m at the market follow on equity program could lead to shareholder dilution if new shares are issued without offsetting benefits in earnings or asset quality.
  • üéÅ The Bronx asset carries an estimated stabilized cap rate of 5.3% initially and 6.1% after renovation, while Queens is guided at 5.4%, giving investors concrete return targets for these projects.
  • üéÅ Long dated leases in Southern California industrial hubs, including one running to 2036, can support more predictable cash flows if tenants perform as expected under their contracts.

What To Watch Going Forward

From here, the key questions are execution and capital deployment. On the leasing side, you can watch how quickly the Rancho Dominguez and Redondo Beach tenants take occupancy, and whether there are any disclosed changes to rent terms or renewal activity. On the acquisitions side, progress updates on permitting, demolition and construction at the Bronx and Queens assets will be important to see if the targeted cap rates and timelines hold. Finally, keep an eye on how much of the US$500m follow on equity capacity Terreno actually uses, and at what share prices, because that will shape the balance between portfolio growth and dilution for existing investors.

  • Bulls argue that this discount plus a DCF fair value of US$12.69 creates a wide valuation gap. The supplied numbers give that argument some support but also highlight why many investors may still be cautious.
    • On one hand, the DCF fair value of US$12.69 is far above the current price of US$2.37 and analysts in the balanced view cite a price target of US$2.50. Together, these figures suggest the market price is sitting below both that DCF mark and the target in the data.
    • On the other, trailing twelve month losses of US$202.3 million and expectations for revenue to decline about 5.3% per year over the next three years show why some investors may see the low P/S and DCF gap as a reflection of ongoing unprofitability rather than a simple mispricing.
Have a look at how bullish investors connect these valuation gaps to their long term view of the business with üêÇ Service Properties Trust Bull Case.

Unprofitable today, forecasts still show losses

  • Over the last twelve months SVC stayed in the red with a net income loss of US$202.3 million and Basic EPS of US$1.22 loss, and the analysis data expects revenue to decline about 6.8% per year over the next three years with no return to profitability in that window.
  • Bears highlight that this mix of falling revenue expectations and ongoing losses keeps financial flexibility tight, and the figures in the analysis line up with several of those concerns.
    • The risk summary flags continued unprofitability, unstable dividends and revenue expected to decline about 5.3% per year, which fits the bearish focus on pressure around cash generation and dividend dependability.
    • At the same time, the same dataset notes a five year trend of losses narrowing by about 19.6% per year, which slightly softens the bearish stance that the business is not making progress on its loss profile at all.
If you want to see how the more cautious investors frame these risks side by side with the numbers, check out the üêª Service Properties Trust Bear Case.
